awd_titl_txt: SCC-IRG TRACK 2: A Novel Architecture for Secure, Energy-Efficient Community-Edge-Clouds with Application in Harlem (SEEC HARLEM) this proposal
awd_abstract_narration:
This project takes a holistic approach to address the technical, legal, and social challenges facing under-served urban communities experiencing a growing digital divide. A novel community-owned edge cloud computing architecture is investigated that disaggregates the edge equipment for lower cost, improved energy efficiency, simplified management and intrinsically stronger security. The project targets a community within Harlem for initial concept exploration.  Indeed, the Harlem community like many diverse urban communities is facing obstacles that extend beyond broadband access and include the entire home, office and IoT/smart city technology eco-system.  Beyond the edge cloud, the project will include development of low-cost KVM (Keyboard, Video, and Mouse) systems that will be used by a diverse set of community members to establish proof of concept and performance metrics for the edge cloud, and identify system usability by community especially as it relates to closing the digital divide.

Prototype hardware and software will be developed to study this architecture in both a lab environment, user trials, and in participatory technology assessments by users in the community. Optimal design rules will be derived for urban communities based on experimental performance data and incorporating user constraints and use cases within the Harlem community. Community ownership will be investigated as a means to overcome longstanding legal and social challenges. The community edge cloud will be studied as a constructed commons and governance models will be explored considering different stakeholder relationships. This project will provide a new dimension to and understanding of edge clouds and community network ownership that can be widely applied in smart city environments elsewhere. Disaggregated devices open up the potential for a new breed of consumer interfaces with dramatically lower cost and energy use - as well as simple software and hardware management and security.  By virtualizing these technologies within the edge cloud, potentially transformative benefits can be realized.  Such technology would provide a powerful tool in combating growing digital divides.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The NSF SCC-IRG project on A Novel Architecture for Secure, Energy Efficient Edge Clouds with Application in Harlem (SEEC HARLEM) conducted research on the potential for the use of virtual desktop computing as a platform for affordable and accessible home and personal computing over edge cloud infrastructure. In particular, as high speed, low latency communication becomes more widely available in 5G and more so in 6G it opens the door to the use of virtual desktop computing throughout a community and delivered over a local edge cloud environment. The sharing of edge computing over virtual desktops is attractive as it enables computing to scale to high performance within the shared infrastructure reducing the cost, energy, and resource burden on the end users and leading to more sustainable growth. Community computing research infrastructure was developed and deployed at the Silicon Harlem NYC Gigabit Center with support from the city of New York and a donation of servers from Microsoft. The technical research explored different virtual desktop environments, including zero clients, and determined networking and computing performance requirements, measured using technical metrics in lab experiments and subjective metrics in user experience trials. The project also engaged with the Harlem community not only in technology trials, but also to discuss the concept of a community edge cloud to provide computing resources shared within the community. The concept of community governance of such shared computing resources was developed and a community advisory board was formed to better understand how a community group might engage with and take on a governing role in such infrastructure. Through this project a vibrant community research environment was created in Harlem which has enabled Silicon Harlem, local schools, and others within the ecosystem to engage with this and other NSF funded research projects and centers. SEEC Harlem established both technical and social foundations for the development of edge cloud computing resources as an enabling technology for inclusive and accessible computing within communities, which will become more relevant and viable as networks expand in scale and performance in the future. 


Last Modified: 09/10/2024
Modified by: Daniel Kilper
